elements.content: A cyano-bridged Fe­(II)–Cr­(III) single-chain magnet designed to ensure a parallel orientation of the axial anisotropy of the building units is reported. This ferromagnetic chain compound consists of a pentagonal bipyramid Fe­(II) complex with Ising-type anisotropy and a dicyanide Cr­(III) complex interlinked through their apical positions. It is characterized by an energy gap for the magnetization reversal of Δeff/k B = 113 K and exhibits magnetic hysteresis with a coercive field of 1400 Oe at 2 K which positions this compound among the very few examples of SCMs with spin reversal barriers above 100 K. The quite remarkable performances of this single-strand SCM are attributed to the alignment of the local anisotropy axes, which is supported by ab initio modeling. A discrete Cr2Fe complex based on the same building units and behaving as a SMM in zero field is also reported.
elements.clean_text: A cyano-bridged Fe(II)-Cr(III) single-chain magnet designed to ensure a parallel orientation of the axial anisotropy of the building units is reported. This ferromagnetic chain compound consists of a pentagonal bipyramid Fe(II) complex with Ising-type anisotropy and a dicyanide Cr(III) complex interlinked through their apical positions. It is characterized by an energy gap for the magnetization reversal of Δeff/k B = 113 K and exhibits magnetic hysteresis with a coercive field of 1400 Oe at 2 K which positions this compound among the very few examples of SCMs with spin reversal barriers above 100 K. The quite remarkable performances of this single-strand SCM are attributed to the alignment of the local anisotropy axes, which is supported by ab initio modeling. A discrete Cr2Fe complex based on the same building units and behaving as a SMM in zero field is also reported.

elements.content: Magnetic anisotropy is a key parameter of the slow relaxation of the magnetization and the magnetic hysteresis displayed by molecular nanomagnets. These unique systems, known as single-molecule magnets (SMM) and single-chain magnets (SCM), are able to retain a net magnetization upon removal of an applied magnetic field and present a magnetic bistability much like bulk 3-D magnets. Whether bulk or nanometric, the macroscopic magnetic anisotropy is related to the anisotropy of the atomic or molecular components of the material; it is therefore desirable to involve large single-ion anisotropies. However, the relative orientations of the local anisotropies should not be neglected in order to maximize the collective effect. In this respect, a chain structure appears more suitable to result in an alignment of the axial anisotropy of the metal ions. Exchange interactions (J) also play an important role in polynuclear compounds as they contribute to the energy splitting of the M S levels. Interestingly, the 1-D correlation in a SCM contributes to the persistence of the magnetization blocking by the energy required to create a domain wall, Δξ = nJS 2 (n = 8 or 4 respectively for an infinite and a finite chain), resulting, for an Ising-type chain, in an energy barrier regulating the spin reversal given by Δ eff = |D|S z 2 + 2Δξ, where D is the axial zero-field splitting (ZFS) parameter and S z is the electron spin projection onto the z axis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Magnetic anisotropy is a key parameter of the slow relaxation of the magnetization and the magnetic hysteresis displayed by molecular nanomagnets. These unique systems, known as single-molecule magnets (SMM) and single-chain magnets (SCM), are able to retain a net magnetization upon removal of an applied magnetic field and present a magnetic bistability much like bulk 3-D magnets. Whether bulk or nanometric, the macroscopic magnetic anisotropy is related to the anisotropy of the atomic or molecular components of the material; it is therefore desirable to involve large single-ion anisotropies. However, the relative orientations of the local anisotropies should not be neglected in order to maximize the collective effect. In this respect, a chain structure appears more suitable to result in an alignment of the axial anisotropy of the metal ions. Exchange interactions (J) also play an important role in polynuclear compounds as they contribute to the energy splitting of the M S levels. Interestingly, the 1-D correlation in a SCM contributes to the persistence of the magnetization blocking by the energy required to create a domain wall, Δξ = nJS 2 (n = 8 or 4 respectively for an infinite and a finite chain), resulting, for an Ising-type chain, in an energy barrier regulating the spin reversal given by Δ eff  = |D|S  z  2 + 2Δξ, where D is the axial zero-field splitting (ZFS) parameter and S  z  is the electron spin projection onto the z axis.

elements.content: Rather surprisingly, only a few examples of SCMs with significant spin reversal barriers (say Δeff/k B > 100 K) have been reported. Most prominent are Co­(II)-radical systems with energy barriers reaching 400 K and cyano-bridged bimetallic double-chain compounds with Δeff/k B up to 253 K; only one single-strand CN-bridged SCM reaches the 100 K threshold. The very limited number of efficient SCMs highlights the challenge of achieving a chemical structure fulfilling all the prerequisites discussed above among which controlling the relative orientations of the local anisotropies might be the trickiest. Herein we report a new entry to this short list, a cyano-bridged Fe­(II)–Cr­(III) SCM designed to ensure a parallel orientation of the axial anisotropy of the building units. This ferromagnetic chain compound consists of a pentagonal bipyramid Fe­(II) complex with Ising-type anisotropy and a dicyanide Cr­(III) complex interlinked through their apical positions. A trimetallic Cr2Fe complex based on the same building units is also reported. Its magnetic behavior allowed validating some of the magnetic parameters obtained for the chain compound; moreover it was found to exhibit a SMM behavior. Ab initio calculations confirmed the nature and the magnitude of the magnetic anisotropy for the Fe­(II) units, the ferromagnetic Fe­(II)–Cr­(III) interaction, and provided precise information on the relative orientations of the axial anisotropy within the 1-D arrangement.

The very limited number of efficient SCMs highlights the challenge of achieving a chemical structure fulfilling all the prerequisites discussed above among which controlling the relative orientations of the local anisotropies might be the trickiest. Herein we report a new entry to this short list, a cyano-bridged Fe(II)-Cr(III) SCM designed to ensure a parallel orientation of the axial anisotropy of the building units. This ferromagnetic chain compound consists of a pentagonal bipyramid Fe(II) complex with Ising-type anisotropy and a dicyanide Cr(III) complex interlinked through their apical positions. A trimetallic Cr2Fe complex based on the same building units is also reported. Its magnetic behavior allowed validating some of the magnetic parameters obtained for the chain compound; moreover it was found to exhibit a SMM behavior. elements.content: The design strategy we have followed consisted of combining a building unit bearing the magnetic anisotropy with an assembling unit selected to promote ferromagnetic interactions. For the former, a Fe­(II) complex with a pentagonal bipyramid environment was chosen owing to its large spin ground state (i.e., S = 2) and uniaxial anisotropy, with D in the order of about −15 cm–1, aligned with the apical positions of the polyhedron. Interestingly, the spin state of such units can be manipulated by light and gives access to switchable nanomagnets. As a complementary unit, a Cr­(III)-cyanide metallo-ligand was best suited to achieve ferromagnetic interactions with the Fe­(II) moiety and results in a large ground spin-state for the elementary magnetic unit of the chain. Moreover, it was shown that N-bound cyanide ligands in the apical positions of a heptacoordinated Fe­(II) contributes to large |D| for this ion. In order to achieve a straight chain organization and to avoid interchain interactions, a trans-dicyano-Cr complex with an organic ligand blocking the equatorial positions was selected. Both the Fe and Cr compounds used as reagents ([FeH2LN3O2NH2Cl2] and K­[CrLN3O2Ph(CN)2], see ) are complexes with a pentagonal bipyramid environment imposed by a pentadentate [N3O2] ligand derived from 2,6-diacetylpyridine-bis­(R-hydrazone) (H2LN3O2R hereafter). The respective ligands differ only by the R-substituents of the terminal hydrazide groups with R = NH2 for Fe and R = Ph for the Cr compounds and their charge.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Design and Synthesis

The design strategy we have followed consisted of combining a building unit bearing the magnetic anisotropy with an assembling unit selected to promote ferromagnetic interactions. For the former, a Fe(II) complex with a pentagonal bipyramid environment was chosen owing to its large spin ground state (i.e., S = 2) and uniaxial anisotropy, with D in the order of about -15 cm-1, aligned with the apical positions of the polyhedron. Interestingly, the spin state of such units can be manipulated by light and gives access to switchable nanomagnets. As a complementary unit, a Cr(III)-cyanide metallo-ligand was best suited to achieve ferromagnetic interactions with the Fe(II) moiety and results in a large ground spin-state for the elementary magnetic unit of the chain. Moreover, it was shown that N-bound cyanide ligands in the apical positions of a heptacoordinated Fe(II) contributes to large |D| for this ion. In order to achieve a straight chain organization and to avoid interchain interactions, a trans-dicyano-Cr complex with an organic ligand blocking the equatorial positions was selected. Both the Fe and Cr compounds used as reagents ([FeH2LN3O2NH2Cl2] and K[CrLN3O2Ph(CN)2], see ) are complexes with a pentagonal bipyramid environment imposed by a pentadentate [N3O2] ligand derived from 2,6-diacetylpyridine-bis(R-hydrazone) (H2LN3O2R hereafter). The respective ligands differ only by the R-substituents of the terminal hydrazide groups with R = NH2 for Fe and R = Ph for the Cr compounds and their charge.

elements.clean_text: 1  Sketch of the Metal Complexes Involved in the Formation of the Fe-Cr Compounds

elements.content: The reactions between K­[Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2] and [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)­Cl2] in a 1/1 ratio in MeOH in the presence of PF6 – yielded a mixture of two compounds identified as a discrete trinuclear complex of formula [{Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2}2Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)]·4.5CH3OH·1.5H2O, 1, and the targeted 1-D coordination polymer of formula [{Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2}­Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)]·PF6·1.25H2O, 2. Selective formation of these compounds was obtained upon adjusting the Cr/Fe reagents’ ratio; pure 1 was formed for a ratio of 2, but specific formation of the chain required reducing the Cr to a ratio of 0.5. The phase purity of the resulting polycrystalline 1 and 2 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction ().
elements.clean_text: The reactions between K[Cr(LN3O2Ph)(CN)2] and [Fe(H2LN3O2NH2)Cl2] in a 1/1 ratio in MeOH in the presence of PF6 - yielded a mixture of two compounds identified as a discrete trinuclear complex of formula [{Cr(LN3O2Ph)(CN)2}2Fe(H2LN3O2NH2)]⋅4.5CH3OH⋅1.5H2O, 1, and the targeted 1-D coordination polymer of formula [{Cr(LN3O2Ph)(CN)2}Fe(H2LN3O2NH2)]⋅PF6⋅1.25H2O, 2. Selective formation of these compounds was obtained upon adjusting the Cr/Fe reagents' ratio; pure 1 was formed for a ratio of 2, but specific formation of the chain required reducing the Cr to a ratio of 0.5. The phase purity of the resulting polycrystalline 1 and 2 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction ().

elements.content: The crystal structure of the trinuclear complex 1 is displayed in . Two Cr­(III) units are linked by one of their CN-groups to a Fe moiety, with coordination taking place in the apical positions of the Fe polyhedron. The molecule is slightly bent due mainly to obtuse Fe–N–C angles (161.5(5) and 162.0(5)°). All the metal centers exhibit a pentagonal bipyramid coordination environment with the pentadentate ligands defining the equatorial plane, while nitrogen or carbon atoms of the cyanide groups occupy the axial positions of Fe and Cr, respectively. The polyhedral shape, evaluated by Continuous Shape Measures performed with SHAPE, revealed a slightly more distorted coordination polyhedron for Fe (). This is also noticeable from the two inequivalent Fe–N axial bonds (2.113(1) and 2.097(1) Å) and the asymmetric positioning of the equatorial ligand with markedly different Fe–O distances (2.313(1) and 2.191(1) Å); other bond distances and angles can be found in . The neutral trinuclear complex crystallized with 4.5 MeOH and 1.5 H2O molecules. These units are packed in pairs possibly stabilized by long H-bonds taking place between the NH2 and the carbonyl groups of adjacent Fe units (N12/H121···O4 1‑x,1‑y,1‑z , 2.864(2)/2.06 Å). The shortest intermolecular Fe···Fe and Cr···Cr distances are 7.577 and 8.542 Å, respectively ().
elements.clean_text:
Molecular Structures

The crystal structure of the trinuclear complex 1 is displayed in . Two Cr(III) units are linked by one of their CN-groups to a Fe moiety, with coordination taking place in the apical positions of the Fe polyhedron. The molecule is slightly bent due mainly to obtuse Fe-N-C angles (161.5(5) and 162.0(5)°). All the metal centers exhibit a pentagonal bipyramid coordination environment with the pentadentate ligands defining the equatorial plane, while nitrogen or carbon atoms of the cyanide groups occupy the axial positions of Fe and Cr, respectively. The polyhedral shape, evaluated by Continuous Shape Measures performed with SHAPE, revealed a slightly more distorted coordination polyhedron for Fe (). This is also noticeable from the two inequivalent Fe-N axial bonds (2.113(1) and 2.097(1) Å) and the asymmetric positioning of the equatorial ligand with markedly different Fe-O distances (2.313(1) and 2.191(1) Å); other bond distances and angles can be found in . The neutral trinuclear complex crystallized with 4.5 MeOH and 1.5 H2O molecules. These units are packed in pairs possibly stabilized by long H-bonds taking place between the NH2 and the carbonyl groups of adjacent Fe units (N12/H121⋅⋅⋅O4 1-x,1-y,1-z , 2.864(2)/2.06 Å). The shortest intermolecular Fe⋅⋅⋅Fe and Cr⋅⋅⋅Cr distances are 7.577 and 8.542 Å, respectively ().

elements.content: The structure of 2 is made up from an asymmetric unit containing two Cr and two Fe units, along with 2 PF6 – anions and 2.5 H2O molecules ( and ). It consists of an 1-D coordination polymer of alternating [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)]2+ and [Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2]− moieties. Each Cr is linked to two Fe, and reciprocally, by means of two bridging cyanides coordinated to the apical positions of the metals’ polyhedra. The chain is quite linear with Fe–N–C angles ranging from 161(5)° to 173.1(5)° and Cr–C–N angles found between 173.8(6)° and 178.0(6)°. Remarkably, although the equatorial planes (defined by O and N atoms of a LN3O2R ligand) of neighboring metal complexes are tilted by ca. 20°, the plans for the Fe units are almost parallel with a deviation for consecutive Fe centers (i.e., the Fe1 and Fe2 sites in ) of only 3.9(2)°. The chains run in parallel along the [0,1,1] direction and are organized in pairs with weak H-bonds between the NH2 and the carbonyl moieties (N26/H261···O8 2‑x,3‑y,2‑z , 2.94(1)/2.10 Å and N12/H121···O4 2‑x,2‑y,2‑z , 2.99(1)/2.15 Å). The shortest interchain Fe···Fe and Cr···Cr distances are 7.884 and 8.381 Å, respectively. The overall chain packing leads to channels where the PF6 – anions are located ().

elements.content: The oxidation state of Fe was confirmed by 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy. The spectra measured at 80 K are characteristic of high-spin Fe­(II) sites and consist of a symmetric doublet (). For 1 it corresponds to the contribution of a single Fe site with a chemical shift (δ) of 1.18(1) mm/s and a quadrupole splitting (Δ) of 2.83(2) mm/s. For 2, the spectrum results from two contributions with δ = 1.205(5) and 1.213(5) mm/s and Δ = 2.39(2) and 1.98(2) mm/s, in agreement with the two Fe sites found in the crystal structure. It can be noticed that the quadrupole splitting for 2 is very similar to that found for a related chain formed by [FeH2LN3O3Ph] and [Ni­(CN)4] units (2.29 mm/s).
elements.clean_text:
Mössbauer Spectroscopy

The oxidation state of Fe was confirmed by 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy. The spectra measured at 80 K are characteristic of high-spin Fe(II) sites and consist of a symmetric doublet (). For 1 it corresponds to the contribution of a single Fe site with a chemical shift (δ) of 1.18(1) mm/s and a quadrupole splitting (Δ) of 2.83(2) mm/s. For 2, the spectrum results from two contributions with δ = 1.205(5) and 1.213(5) mm/s and Δ = 2.39(2) and 1.98(2) mm/s, in agreement with the two Fe sites found in the crystal structure. It can be noticed that the quadrupole splitting for 2 is very similar to that found for a related chain formed by [FeH2LN3O3Ph] and [Ni(CN)4] units (2.29 mm/s).

elements.content: Static and dynamic magnetic properties were investigated for the two compounds. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility, χM, was measured between 2 and 300 K; the results are plotted as χM T = f­(T) where χM is given per mole of Cr2Fe and CrFe units for 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Static and dynamic magnetic properties were investigated for the two compounds. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility, χM, was measured between 2 and 300 K; the results are plotted as χM T = f(T) where χM is given per mole of Cr2Fe and CrFe units for 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: The χM T value obtained for 1 at 300 K is 7.51 cm3 K mol–1, in agreement with the Curie contributions expected for two S = 3/2 and one S = 2 (with g Fe > 2.0). Upon cooling, χM T gradually increases to 12.50 cm3 mol–1 K at 6.8 K confirming ferromagnetic Fe–Cr interactions. The slight decrease below 6.8 K can be attributed to the ZFS and possibly intermolecular interactions (). The isothermal field dependence of the magnetization recorded in the range of 2 to 8 K ( inset) confirms the occurrence of ferromagnetic Fe–Cr interactions. The lower magnetization reached for 50 kOe (e.g., 7.36 μB at 2 K) compared to the 10 μB expected for an S = 5 can be attributed to the anisotropy of the Fe center.

elements.content: The strength of the exchange interaction between Cr and Fe (J, reference Hamiltonian is given in ) and the ZFS splitting parameter D for Fe­(II) were evaluated by modeling concomitantly the χM T = f­(T) and M = f(H) behaviors. A mean-field parameter, zj′, was introduced to account for the decrease of χM T for lowest temperatures. Modeling was performed with PHI; the best fit to the experimental data was obtained for J = 4.11 ± 0.07 cm–1, D = −25 cm–1, zj′ = −0.015 ± 0.001 cm–1, g Cr = 2.0 (fixed), and g Fe = 2.15 (). The ferromagnetic Fe–Cr interaction found for 1 is consistent with literature data, and the small value of zj′ confirms the anticipated very weak intermolecular interactions. The ZFS parameter D of −25 cm–1 appears slightly large by comparison to the values usually reported for related pentagonal bipyramid Fe­(II) complexes; however, ab initio calculations (vide infra) confirm a strong magnetic anisotropy for this Fe unit. Ĥ = − J ( Ŝ C r 1 · Ŝ F e + Ŝ C r 2 · Ŝ F e )

elements.content: AC susceptibility studies for 1 revealed a slow relaxation of the magnetization in zero field and a temperature dependence of the relaxation time in agreement with an SMM behavior; details can be found in the . This trimetallic SMM is characterized by an effective energy barrier for spin flip of Δeff/k B = 22 K (15 cm–1) and a pre-exponential factor τ0 = 3.8 × 10–8 s.

elements.content: The χM T value of 5.9 cm3 K mol–1 found for the chain 2 at 300 K is in agreement with the expected Curie contributions for one Cr­(III) and one high-spin Fe­(II) with g Fe > 2. This value increases very slightly as temperature is reduced to 50 K afterwards a steep increase to a maximum of 39.0 cm3 K mol–1 at 8 K is observed, followed by a quick decrease to reach 8.6 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K (). Such a behavior is in agreement with a ferromagnetic chain. The decrease of χM T below 8 K was found to result from a saturation effect () due to chains of finite size (vide infra) and not from antiferromagnetic interchain interactions. Short chain lengths may be inherent to the synthetic procedure of the polycrystalline sample, i.e. fast crystallization. The χM T behavior has been modeled between 300 and 8 K using an expression of the susceptibility for Heisenberg linear chains with alternating spins. The ZFS of the Fe­(II) center was not taken into account but is expected to contribute mainly to the behavior below 10 K. Best fit yielded J = 2.68(4) cm–1, g Fe = 2.10(4), and gCr = 2.0 (fixed), in good agreement with the ferromagnetic Cr–Fe interaction found in 1.

elements.content: For anisotropic Heisenberg or Ising-like one-dimensional systems, Glauber predicted the exponential dependence of χM T with decreasing temperature in the absence of a dc field, following the expression χM T = C eff exp­(Δξ/k B T), where C eff is the effective Curie constant, Δξ is the correlation energy, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. For 2, the plot of ln­(χ′M T) as a function of 1/T, where χ′M is the in-phase magnetic susceptibility measured in the absence of a dc field with an oscillating AC-field of 3 Oe (ν = 100 Hz), shows a linear variation between 10 and 30 K ( inset) that leads to Δξ/k B = 20.6 K. In the Ising limit and considering finite size chains, the Cr–Fe exchange interaction can be roughly estimated from the expression Δξ = 4|J|S Fe × S Cr giving 2J = 2.4 cm–1, a value consistent with the value deduced from the χM T vs T behavior.
elements.clean_text: For anisotropic Heisenberg or Ising-like one-dimensional systems, Glauber predicted the exponential dependence of χM T with decreasing temperature in the absence of a dc field, following the expression χM T = C eff exp(Δξ/k B T), where C eff is the effective Curie constant, Δξ is the correlation energy, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. For 2, the plot of ln(χ'M T) as a function of 1/T, where χ'M is the in-phase magnetic susceptibility measured in the absence of a dc field with an oscillating AC-field of 3 Oe (ν = 100 Hz), shows a linear variation between 10 and 30 K ( inset) that leads to Δξ/k B = 20.6 K. In the Ising limit and considering finite size chains, the Cr-Fe exchange interaction can be roughly estimated from the expression Δξ = 4|J|S Fe × S Cr giving 2J = 2.4 cm-1, a value consistent with the value deduced from the χM T vs T behavior.

elements.content: AC susceptibility for chain 2 revealed frequency dependent in-phase (χ′M) and out-of-phase (χ″M) signals in zero field below 10 K ( and ). Analysis of the Cole–Cole plots, χ″M = f(χ′M), indicated a distribution width (α) of the relaxation time ranging from α = 0.51 to 0.1 between 3.5 and 7 K (). Such a broad distribution is likely related to a distribution of the chain length or random defects in the coordination polymers (vide infra).

elements.content: The relaxation times (τ) were deduced from χ″M = f(ν) behaviors using a generalized Debye model, and their temperature dependence was analyzed with the Arrhenius law (τ = τ0 exp­(Δeff/k B T)). A crossover between two thermally activated relaxation modes is found at about 5.6 K (), which can be related to the occurrence of defects along the chains. The existence of infinite- and finite-size regime in the relaxation mechanisms of single-chain magnets was theoretically postulated by Glauber’s probability laws; their relative energy gaps are respectively expressed by Δ1 = |D|S z 2 + 2Δξ and Δ2 = |D|S z 2 + Δξ. For 2, the infinite-size regime is characterized by Δ1/k B = 113 K and τ0 = 1.62 × 10–11 s, while for the finite-size regime Δ2/k B = 94 K and τ0 = 5.7 × 10–10 s. We can notice that Δ1/k B – Δ2/k B = 19 K which is extremely close to the experimental value of Δξ/k B, in agreement with the theory. The average number of [FeCr] units in a chain (n ≈ 2ξ ≈ exp­(Δξ/k B T*)) is estimated to be 40 for T* = 5.6 K and Δξ/k B = 20.6 K, which correspond to a mean chain length of L ≈ 35 nm. An estimation of the effective anisotropy parameter of the repeating unit, D CrFe, can be made from Δ2 = |D CrFe|·S CrFe 2 + Δξ, yielding |D CrFe| = 4 cm–1.

elements.content: The occurrence of a thermally activated magnetic relaxation through a substantial energy barrier in 2 was confirmed by the observation of magnetization hysteresis loops (). At 2 K, a coercive field of 1400 Oe and a remnant magnetization of 1.0 μB are observed; at 3 K, a narrow loop is still found, whereas at 5 K it is closed. The M vs H behavior at 2 K displays a marked sigmoidal shape below 2 kOe (), a feature also visible at 3 K but in a reduced field domain (1.2 kOe) and vanishing at 5 K. Such behavior is usually found for metamagnetic material but has also been reported for molecular nanomagnets showing magnetic hysteresis. As already mentioned, no evidence for a transition to an antiferromagnetic phase was found for 2 at low T (). For all investigated T, the magnetization for higher fields does not saturate but steadily increases to reach 4.3 μB for 5 T; a behavior consistent with significant magnetic anisotropy.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior exhibited by chain 2, especially the AC susceptibility and magnetic hysteresis, is consistent with a slow relaxation of the magnetization. The energy gap for the magnetization reversal, Δeff/k B = 113 K, is quite remarkable when compared to the modest anisotropy of the Fe unit. This is even more striking when the performances of other SCM based on related heptacoordinated Fe­(II) moieties are considered. For instance, for a cyano-bridged Fe–Nb SCM we have reported previously, Δ/k B is smaller by 40 K despite a much stronger exchange interaction between metal centers. A rationale for such a marked difference could be found in the relative orientation of the uniaxial anisotropy of the Fe units (with easy axes oriented along the apical coordination sites). In the Fe–Nb SCM, the local easy axes are severely tilted, whereas they are virtually aligned in parallel for 2. The contribution of a single ion D to the in-chain D chain is D × cos2(γ) where γ is the angle between the local z-axis and the molecular z-axis (for 2 the chain-growth direction). Moreover, for γ > 0 the local D will also contribute to other molecular anisotropy components of the chain, thus increasing the transverse anisotropy. It is therefore intuitive that the situation in 2 is optimal and, consequently, leads to a notably increased energy gap for the magnetization reversal.

elements.content: Ab initio calculations have been performed on 1 and 2 in order to confirm the magnitude and nature of the magnetic anisotropy of the Fe­(II) metal ions, to determine the orientation of the easy magnetic axes, and to estimate the Fe–Cr exchange interactions J i . A procedure already successfully applied to Fe­(II) with the same pentadentate ligand has been followed to evaluate the magnetic anisotropy parameters D and E. As it is widely described in these publications only the main aspects are reported in the section.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

 Ab initio calculations have been performed on 1 and 2 in order to confirm the magnitude and nature of the magnetic anisotropy of the Fe(II) metal ions, to determine the orientation of the easy magnetic axes, and to estimate the Fe-Cr exchange interactions J  i . A procedure already successfully applied to Fe(II) with the same pentadentate ligand has been followed to evaluate the magnetic anisotropy parameters D and E. As it is widely described in these publications only the main aspects are reported in the  section.

elements.content: Results for D, E, and of the different magnetic couplings J ij of the Heisenberg–Dirac-van Vleck model Hamiltonian between the states of spin Si = 2 and Sj = 3/2 (Ĥ = −∑⟨i,j⟩ J ij S ⃗ ̂ i · S ⃗ ̂ j ) are reported in , while the easy magnetic axes are depicted in (a movie showing rotating views can be found in the ). For the Fe­(II) ions D is relatively large, with −17 to −20 cm–1, while it is almost negligible for the Cr­(III) ions. The easy magnetic axes of the Fe centers are pointing along the apical coordination sites of the complex, whereas the x and y directions are located in the equatorial plane (see the ). As a result, the easy axes for Fe in 2 are slightly tilted with respect to the chain-growth direction (17.2° for Fe1 and 16.7° for Fe2) but are almost parallel with an angle of 10.6° between the axes of Fe1 and Fe2. All these results strongly support the conclusions drawn from experiment.

The energy gap reached for 2 shows that even a modest local uniaxial anisotropy combined with a rather weak exchange interaction but with the single-ion anisotropies almost aligned can outperform many of the SCM based on more anisotropic units and stronger exchange interactions. These results strongly suggest that the relative orientation of the local uniaxial anisotropies can have a significant contribution to the overall Δeff/k B and should be a parameter seriously taken into account in the search of SCM with augmented performances.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

The energy gap reached for 2 shows that even a modest local uniaxial anisotropy combined with a rather weak exchange interaction but with the single-ion anisotropies almost aligned can outperform many of the SCM based on more anisotropic units and stronger exchange interactions. These results strongly suggest that the relative orientation of the local uniaxial anisotropies can have a significant contribution to the overall Δeff/k B and should be a parameter seriously taken into account in the search of SCM with augmented performances.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses

All the syntheses were carried out under N2 using Schlenk techniques, and the samples for the characterizations were prepared in a glovebox. The complexes K[Cr(LN3O2Ph)(CN)2] and [Fe(H2LN3O2NH2)Cl2] were synthesized following the reported procedures. Diethyl ether was purified using an Innovative Technologies solvent purification system, while the alcohol and water solvents were distilled under N2 prior to use.

elements.content: A solution of [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)­Cl2] (0.125 g, 0.31 mmol) in 10 mL of MeOH and 1.8 mL of H2O was slowly added to a solution of K­[Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2] (0.336 g, 0.62 mmol) dissolved in 20 mL of MeOH. A red solid slowly appeared during the addition. The suspension was stirred overnight at room temperature. The polycrystalline solid was filtered and washed with MeOH followed by Et2O yielding 215 mg (46%) of 1. The phase purity of this solid was confirmed by PXRD (see ). Single crystals suitable for X-ray crystal structure studies were obtained by slow interdiffusion in a 1 cm diameter Schlenk tube of a solution of [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)­Cl2] (0.015 g, 0.03 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) and 0.1 mL of H2O, layered with 1 mL of MeOH, and with a solution of K­[Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2] (0.020 g, 0.06 mmol) in 4 mL of MeOH. The crystals were isolated after 1 night. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2919 (m), 2850 (w), 2135 (w with shoulder at 2159), 1671 (s), 1634 (w), 1604 (w), 1586 (w), 1519 (s), 1495 (sh), 1455 (w), 1425 (m), 1384 (s), 1343 (sh), 1307 (w), 1274 (w), 1191 (w), 1173 (w), 1160 (w), 1138 (w), 1120 (w), 1094 (w), 1071 (w), 1050 (m), 1026 (w), 1011 (w), 994 (m), 935 (w), 906 (m), 846 (m), 808 (w), 761 (w), 739 (sh), 714 (m), 683 (m), 645 (w). elements.content: Magnetic measurements were carried out with a Quantum Design MPMS-5S SQUID magnetometer on freshly isolated polycrystalline powders mixed with grease and held in gelatin capsules. Data have been collected with an applied field of 1 kOe (or as stated otherwise) between 300 and 2 K and corrected for the diamagnetic contribution by using Pascal’s tables and for the sample holder. The field dependences of the magnetization were measured in magnetic fields up to 5 T. The absence of ferromagnetic impurities was checked by recording the M vs H behavior at 100 K. 57Fe Mössbauer spectra were recorded on a constant acceleration conventional spectrometer with a 50 mCi source of 57Co (Rh matrix) equipped with an MD 306 Oxford cryostat. The absorber was a powder sample enclosed in a 20 mm diameter cylindrical plastic sample holder, the size of which had been determined to optimize the absorption. A least-squares computer program was used to fit the Mössbauer parameters and determine their standard deviations (given in parentheses). Isomer shift values (δ) are relative to iron foil at 293 K. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed with a Perkin–Elmer spectrum GX 2000 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed with a Perkin–Elmer 2400 series II instrument.

Physical Measurements

The field dependences of the magnetization were measured in magnetic fields up to 5 T. The absence of ferromagnetic impurities was checked by recording the M vs H behavior at 100 K. 57Fe Mössbauer spectra were recorded on a constant acceleration conventional spectrometer with a 50 mCi source of 57Co (Rh matrix) equipped with an MD 306 Oxford cryostat. The absorber was a powder sample enclosed in a 20 mm diameter cylindrical plastic sample holder, the size of which had been determined to optimize the absorption. A least-squares computer program was used to fit the Mössbauer parameters and determine their standard deviations (given in parentheses). Isomer shift values (δ) are relative to iron foil at 293 K. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed with a Perkin-Elmer spectrum GX 2000 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 series II instrument.

elements.content: Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were coated with paratone oil and mounted onto the goniometer under N2 flux. The X-ray crystallographic data were obtained at low temperature from an Apex2 Bruker diffractometer (MoKα radiation source), equipped with an Oxford Cryosystem. The structures have been solved using Superflip and refined by means of least-squares procedures on F using the PC version of the program CRYSTALS. The scattering factors for all the atoms were used as listed in the International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Absorption correction was performed using a multiscan procedure. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms were usually located in a difference map except for some solvate molecules, but those attached to carbon atoms were systematically repositioned geometrically. The H atoms were initially refined with soft restraints on the bond lengths and angles to regularize their geometry and Uiso (H) (in the range 1.2–1.5 times Ueq of the parent atom), after which the positions were refined with riding constraints. It was not possible to resolve diffuse electron-density residuals (enclosed solvent molecules). Some cocrystallized solvent molecules were squeezed with the SQUEEZE facility from PLATON: 4.5 MeOH and 1.5 H2O in 1 and 1 H2O for 2 (per asymmetric unit). Crystallographic information for all the complexes is gathered in . ORTEP plots and selected bond distances and angles are given in the . The cif have been deposited at The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre under the references 1835326 (1) and 1835327 (2); they can be obtained from www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: In a first step, CASSCF and NEVPT2 methods have been used to reach an accurate evaluation of the electronic wave functions and energies of all the d-d states: for Fe­(II), the active space is formed by six electrons spanned over the five 3d orbitals. Five states of spin S = 2 and 45 states of spin S = 1 were calculated on an average set of molecular orbitals. For Cr­(III) metal ions, three electrons are active, and ten states of spin S = 3/2 and 40 states of spin S = 1/2 states were calculated. The state-interaction spin–orbit method was then used to take into account the spin–orbit couplings between the M S components of all the states computed at the first step. Finally, the extraction of both the magnetic anisotropy parameters D and E and the orientation of the magnetic axes have been performed using the effective Hamiltonian method. The magnetic couplings between Fe­(II) and Cr­(III) metal ions were obtained by assimilating the energies of the S = 7/2, 5/2, 3/2, and 1/2 low-energy states to those of the Heisenberg–Dirac-van Vleck model Hamiltonian. These energies were computed at the CAS­(7/7)­SCF and NEVPT2 levels.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Information

In a first step, CASSCF and NEVPT2 methods have been used to reach an accurate evaluation of the electronic wave functions and energies of all the d-d states: for Fe(II), the active space is formed by six electrons spanned over the five 3d orbitals. Five states of spin S = 2 and 45 states of spin S = 1 were calculated on an average set of molecular orbitals. For Cr(III) metal ions, three electrons are active, and ten states of spin S = 3/2 and 40 states of spin S = 1/2 states were calculated. The state-interaction spin-orbit method was then used to take into account the spin-orbit couplings between the M S components of all the states computed at the first step. Finally, the extraction of both the magnetic anisotropy parameters D and E and the orientation of the magnetic axes have been performed using the effective Hamiltonian method. The magnetic couplings between Fe(II) and Cr(III) metal ions were obtained by assimilating the energies of the S = 7/2, 5/2, 3/2, and 1/2 low-energy states to those of the Heisenberg-Dirac-van Vleck model Hamiltonian. These energies were computed at the CAS(7/7)SCF and NEVPT2 levels.

elements.content: X-ray geometrical structures (and DFT optimization for the position of the H atoms only) have been used to construct mono- and bimetallic fragments on which calculations were performed. For assessing magnetic anisotropy, the fragments consisted of the Fe­(II) (or Cr­(III) ion), the whole pentadentate ligand, and the two NC–. For magnetic coupling, the fragments contained two nearest-neighbors metal ions and the ligands of their coordination spheres. +2/+3 charges have been introduced in order to mimic the electrostatic effect of the nearest Fe2+/Cr3+ ion. All calculations have been performed using the ORCA code. Def2 rich atomic basis sets were considered: calculations on monometallic fragments were performed using 11s6p5d4f2g for Fe and Cr, 6s3p2d for C, N, and O, and 3s1p for H DKH2 contracted atomic basis sets; calculations on bimetallic fragments were performed using 6s4p4d1f for Fe and Cr, 5s3p2d1f for C, N, and O, and 3s1p for H atomic basis sets.

A solution of [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)­Cl2] (0.125 g, 0.31 mmol) in 10 mL of MeOH and 1.8 mL of H2O was slowly added to a solution of K­[Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2] (0.336 g, 0.62 mmol) dissolved in 20 mL of MeOH. A red solid slowly appeared during the addition. The suspension was stirred overnight at room temperature. The polycrystalline solid was filtered and washed with MeOH followed by Et2O yielding 215 mg (46%) of 1. The phase purity of this solid was confirmed by PXRD (see ). Single crystals suitable for X-ray crystal structure studies were obtained by slow interdiffusion in a 1 cm diameter Schlenk tube of a solution of [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)­Cl2] (0.015 g, 0.03 mmol) in MeOH (2 mL) and 0.1 mL of H2O, layered with 1 mL of MeOH, and with a solution of K­[Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2] (0.020 g, 0.06 mmol) in 4 mL of MeOH. The crystals were isolated after 1 night. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2919 (m), 2850 (w), 2135 (w with shoulder at 2159), 1671 (s), 1634 (w), 1604 (w), 1586 (w), 1519 (s), 1495 (sh), 1455 (w), 1425 (m), 1384 (s), 1343 (sh), 1307 (w), 1274 (w), 1191 (w), 1173 (w), 1160 (w), 1138 (w), 1120 (w), 1094 (w), 1071 (w), 1050 (m), 1026 (w), 1011 (w), 994 (m), 935 (w), 906 (m), 846 (m), 808 (w), 761 (w), 739 (sh), 714 (m), 683 (m), 645 (w). [Cr­(L<sup>N3O2Ph</sup>)­(CN)<sub>2</sub>Fe­(H<sub>2</sub>L<sup>N3O2NH2</sup>)]­(PF<sub>6</sub>)·1.25H<sub>2</sub>O, <bold>2</bold>

K­[Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2] (0.167 g, 0.31 mmol) in 16 mL of MeOH was added dropwise to [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)­Cl2] (0.250 g, 0.62 mmol) and NH4PF6 (0.4 g, 2.45 mmol) dissolved in 25 mL of MeOH and 1.5 mL of H2O. A red/brown solid slowly appeared during the addition. The suspension was stirred overnight at room temperature. The solid was filtered and washed with MeOH followed by Et2O (5 mL), yielding 140 mg (45% based on Cr) of 2. Phase purity of this polycrystalline solid was confirmed by PXRD, see . Crystallization conditions to get single crystals suitable for X-ray structure analysis: A solution of [Fe­(H2LN3O2NH2)­Cl2] (0.015 g, 0.03 mmol) and NH4PF6 (0.02 g, 0.12 mmol) in MeOH (1 mL) and H2O (0.1 mL) was placed in a 1 cm diameter Schlenk tube and layered with 2 mL of MeOH. A solution of [Cr­(LN3O2Ph)­(CN)2]K (0.010 g, 0.015 mmol) in 3 mL of MeOH was carefully added on top. After a few days 10.5 mg (56% based on Cr) of crystals was isolated. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2919 (m), 2850 (w), 2138 (w), 1670 (s), 1634 (w), 1604 (w), 1586 (w), 1540 (sh), 1520 (s), 1495 (sh), 1430 (w), 1384 (s), 1300 (w), 1275 (w), 1261 (w), 1194 (w), 1175 (w), 1163 (w), 1120 (w), 1094 (m), 1068 (w), 1051 (m), 1023 (w), 998 (sh),898 (sh), 838 (s), 813 (sh), 764 (w), 743 (w), 712 (m), 692 (m). Elemental analysis (%) calcd. for C36H36.5CrF6FeN14O5.25P: C 43.14; H 3.67; N 19.57; found: C 43.26; H 3.73; N 19.65.

cln_elements.content:
A cyano-bridged Fe­(II)–Cr­(III) single-chain magnet designed to ensure a parallel orientation of the axial anisotropy of the building units is reported. This ferromagnetic chain compound consists of a pentagonal bipyramid Fe­(II) complex with Ising-type anisotropy and a dicyanide Cr­(III) complex interlinked through their apical positions. It is characterized by an energy gap for the magnetization reversal of Δeff/k B = 113 K and exhibits magnetic hysteresis with a coercive field of 1400 Oe at 2 K which positions this compound among the very few examples of SCMs with spin reversal barriers above 100 K. The quite remarkable performances of this single-strand SCM are attributed to the alignment of the local anisotropy axes, which is supported by ab initio modeling. A discrete Cr2Fe complex based on the same building units and behaving as a SMM in zero field is also reported.

[{Cr­(L<sup>N3O2Ph</sup>)­(CN)<sub>2</sub>}<sub>2</sub>Fe­(H<sub>2</sub>L<sup>N3O2NH2</sup>)], <bold>1</bold>

The χM T value obtained for 1 at 300 K is 7.51 cm3 K mol–1, in agreement with the Curie contributions expected for two S = 3/2 and one S = 2 (with g Fe > 2.0). Upon cooling, χM T gradually increases to 12.50 cm3 mol–1 K at 6.8 K confirming ferromagnetic Fe–Cr interactions. The slight decrease below 6.8 K can be attributed to the ZFS and possibly intermolecular interactions (). The isothermal field dependence of the magnetization recorded in the range of 2 to 8 K ( inset) confirms the occurrence of ferromagnetic Fe–Cr interactions. The lower magnetization reached for 50 kOe (e.g., 7.36 μB at 2 K) compared to the 10 μB expected for an S = 5 can be attributed to the anisotropy of the Fe center.

AC susceptibility studies for 1 revealed a slow relaxation of the magnetization in zero field and a temperature dependence of the relaxation time in agreement with an SMM behavior; details can be found in the . This trimetallic SMM is characterized by an effective energy barrier for spin flip of Δeff/k B = 22 K (15 cm–1) and a pre-exponential factor τ0 = 3.8 × 10–8 s.

1-D [{Cr­(L<sup>N3O2Ph</sup>)­(CN)<sub>2</sub>}­Fe­(H<sub>2</sub>L<sup>N3O2NH2</sup>)]·PF<sub>6</sub>, <bold>2</bold>

The χM T value of 5.9 cm3 K mol–1 found for the chain 2 at 300 K is in agreement with the expected Curie contributions for one Cr­(III) and one high-spin Fe­(II) with g Fe > 2. This value increases very slightly as temperature is reduced to 50 K afterwards a steep increase to a maximum of 39.0 cm3 K mol–1 at 8 K is observed, followed by a quick decrease to reach 8.6 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K (). Such a behavior is in agreement with a ferromagnetic chain. The decrease of χM T below 8 K was found to result from a saturation effect () due to chains of finite size (vide infra) and not from antiferromagnetic interchain interactions. Short chain lengths may be inherent to the synthetic procedure of the polycrystalline sample, i.e. fast crystallization. The χM T behavior has been modeled between 300 and 8 K using an expression of the susceptibility for Heisenberg linear chains with alternating spins. The ZFS of the Fe­(II) center was not taken into account but is expected to contribute mainly to the behavior below 10 K. Best fit yielded J = 2.68(4) cm–1, g Fe = 2.10(4), and gCr = 2.0 (fixed), in good agreement with the ferromagnetic Cr–Fe interaction found in 1.

The occurrence of a thermally activated magnetic relaxation through a substantial energy barrier in 2 was confirmed by the observation of magnetization hysteresis loops (). At 2 K, a coercive field of 1400 Oe and a remnant magnetization of 1.0 μB are observed; at 3 K, a narrow loop is still found, whereas at 5 K it is closed. The M vs H behavior at 2 K displays a marked sigmoidal shape below 2 kOe (), a feature also visible at 3 K but in a reduced field domain (1.2 kOe) and vanishing at 5 K. Such behavior is usually found for metamagnetic material but has also been reported for molecular nanomagnets showing magnetic hysteresis. As already mentioned, no evidence for a transition to an antiferromagnetic phase was found for 2 at low T (). For all investigated T, the magnetization for higher fields does not saturate but steadily increases to reach 4.3 μB for 5 T; a behavior consistent with significant magnetic anisotropy.
